awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Weather Risk, Climate Adaptation and Farmer Decision Making in the Southwestern United States
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will focus on analyzing financial support and information available to different groups of farmers in the southwestern United States, all of whom are facing increasing weather challenges, especially in the form of water shortages. The project will analyze how different sets of resources and access to those resources may enhance farm resilience to ecological and economic challenges. By analyzing the institutional and social influences on farm decisions, the research will extend understandings of farmers' choices and the ways in which those decisions shape the farm landscape. It will also broaden understanding of how farmers in the industrialized world deal with climatic change. The research will investigate how U.S. farm policy may be an effective tool for decreasing farm vulnerability to weather risks. It will also highlight current access of underrepresented minority farmers to farm support programs. In addition, the project will assess the relative vulnerability of farmers of different ethnicities with a variety of farm production styles and sizes. As such, the project will analyze the differential effects of agricultural institutions across contrasting farm types, highlighting for whom U.S. farm policy may be effective in supporting responses to a variable climate. To offer farmers and policy-makers a deeper understanding of how differing access to resources may be affecting farms, the researchers will share the results of the research through presentations and a publication. 

The project builds on past research in network political ecology, applying the framework for the first time to industrialized agriculture. Network political ecology analyzes the system in which an actor, often a farmer, operates. It parses the influences on individuals' decisions and analyzes which factors have the greatest power over the decisions that are ultimately made. Factors may include such influences as economic shifts, ecological conditions and social context. The framework also determines how those factors interact in the production of decisions. The research will focus on the question: How do farmers' institutional ties, mediated by their network of social relations, shape their farming strategies in the face of current and future weather risks? Through a series of interviews with a variety of farmers in two New Mexico counties, the researchers will identify sets of farmer networks to analyze. Interviews will center on farmers' decisions and which factors have most significantly influenced those decisions. Farmers will aid the researchers in constructing their decision-making histories. The researchers will interview other key actors, such as extension agents and insurers, to gain additional information about how institutions shape farm decisions and how social relationships with individuals in institutions may affect the way farmers ultimately use information and resources. Interview data will be analyzed to determine how key decisions and their relationships to weather events differ among different networks of farmers. Particular attention will be paid to farmer decisions that result in highly positive outcomes for farms in years when weather presents significant challenges.

por.por_cntn:
The project analyzed the ways in which differing access to information and resources shapes the decisions of farmers in the southwestern United States. Building on preliminary fieldwork conducted in 2012 during a severe drought in New Mexico, the project focused on two sites in southern and eastern New Mexico that experienced adverse effects of drought. The co-PI interviewed farmers and other members of farmers’ agricultural networks to learn how resources and information were important to farmers’ decisions before, during, and after the drought. Additional county and state level data was collected to add broader context to the farmer interviews.

 

The project built on past research in network political ecology, applying the framework to the Global North. The method allowed for analysis of the larger system in which farmers operate, assessing the relative importance of different aspects of farmers’ agricultural networks on the decisions that they make on their farms. The project, like past studies, found that market shifts do often play an important role in the decisions farmers make, but that ecological conditions and social context have a strong influence on what farmers choose to do. The network within which farmers were located, based on geography, crops grown, availability of markets, sources of information from researchers and retailers, family influence, and neighbors, all played a role in mediating the influence of farm policy and programs. Farmers with more extensive networks of contacts, especially those with networks that extended well beyond the confines of the state, were more likely to make decisions that were both unusual within their geographic networks and also produced successful outcomes on their farms. More extensive networks often allowed farmers to supersede constraints provided by other elements of their networks. Such farmers thus provided examples of ways farming systems could be successfully transformed to deal with future change.

Network constraints that were important to farmers included, but ranged well beyond, drought and related environmental challenges. Agricultural policies that New Mexican farmers perceived to be formulated for larger scale producers in California and the Midwest, for example, often limited opportunities to remain in or expand upon production of preferred crops. Farmers’ preferred crops were often better adapted to drier conditions than those crops that policy encouraged them to adopt. Moreover, increasingly restrictive immigration policies were perceived by farmers as limiting their crop choices to those that could be grown without extensive labor inputs. As farm labor was lost to the Mexican side of the border, production of regionally important crops like chili pepper tended to move south over the border, only to be imported to the U.S. by processors and undercutting local production.

 

The use of network political ecology permitted a focus on extensive and detailed local histories of farmer decision-making while making clear ties to important regional and national influences on farming. The important role of weather in day-to-day decisions was mediated, in both positive and negative ways, by differing aspects of agricultural institutions including crop insurance, water governance, GAP certification, and organic certification. More innovative farmers tended to be those who had learned how to ensure that the constraints created by certain agricultural policy provisions did not hinder the continued change and growth of their farming operations.

 

Results of the research are scheduled to be shared with farmers and other stakeholders after completion of the project write-up. Meetings will be organized and a written report will be shared with stakeholders. Feedback from meetings will be used to produce a more targeted written report.
